I cannot reproduce. 
- which editor?
- is the file shared with a team provider?
- please provide your General > Editors > Text Editors > Quick Diff settings

Strange. 

Inspecting the code in RangeDifferencer, this could happen if a IRangeComparator
with a negative-length region was used.

Inspecting DocumentLineDiffer, I believe we cannot compute a negative range,
although this behavior is never asserted (it probably should).

(In reply to comment #0)
> The text editor on a small text file seems to have problems. I typed a line at
> the end of the file, the text comes out mixed up. 

This indicates that the document structures were already corrupt after typing
the new line. Paul, can you confirm that the document was already corrupt (i.e.
not showing the expected contents) after entering the new line, but that the
exception only showed up when you pressed 'Delete'?

> Then I do a delete and I get: java.lang.NegativeArraySizeException

If line information on the document is not correct, it is of course possible
that we get bogus line ranges. In that case, the exception in comment 0 is
merely a symptom of another problem.
Paul, please reopen after providing the additional info.

(In reply to comment #3)
> Paul, please reopen after providing the additional info.

Here's the sequence of events:
1. Installed rc1 and opened up with an M6 workspace.
2. Downloaded plugin CDT 2.1.1
3. Created a new C++ managed workspace and imported a bunch of files
4. Editted some files in the CDT editor
5. In the navigator I right clicked and selected Text Editor for a small text
source file. File was maybe 20 lines long.
6. I went to the end of the file and did CR and typed in the word Transport. I
looked at it on the screen and it was all jumbled up. I figured it was just my
bad typing gotten worse. I moved the caret to the end of the string and started
doing deletes. That's when the error occured.

I actually think that the bad text that was entered was a problem with the
editor, not with my typing. Hope this helps.

Paul

We need some more info, since we cannot reproduce on plain Eclipse SDK yet:

- can you reproduce if you skip step 3. and in step 4. you create a Java project?

see also

We need more details.
*** Bug 101212 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 101762 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Tim, in bug 101762 comment 3 you said that you had a reproducable case:

> It in fact requires two steps, which
> when used within my open project are repeatable.

- Would it be possible to attach your project?
- Would it be possible to attach your workbench and project settings?
  - General > Editors > Text Editors > Quick Diff  preferences (which provider etc.)
  - is folding enabled, are any parts of your file folded when the problem occurs?
  - any additional plugins installed?
  - do you work with "Show source of selected element only" enabled, ie. do you
work on the entire file or one method at a time?

Yes, it was on saturday..I'm not sure i snapshotted the project at that stage
though. Let me look to see if I can get it back (sorry)

The project is large and has a lot of dependencies (bdb, several external jni
components)... i'd be happy to run a debug build to pin it down if that helps -
just thinking it might be easier?

I've rolled back the project to the nearest snapshot to when the problem
occurred but I can't reproduce it - sorry. 

> the end of the file, the text comes out mixed up. 

I can confirm too that after the assertion failure typing text or anything in
the editor window caused random characters to appear at incorrect positions.

No parts were folded at the time. QuickDiff is with the CVS copy. A version of
the CDT is installed but not in use (all C projects closed). Working on the
whole file at once.

I will keep trying to reproduce it but it seems pretty elusive...
*** Bug 103930 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 108768 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

DocumentLineDiffer already checks for a number of RuntimeExceptions that may
occur during document access. 

Added NegativeArraySizeException to that list.

Available > 20050905

>Did this fix go into 3.1.2? 
"your releases/milestone" >= "Target Milestone" ==> fix is in.
"your releases/milestone" < "Target Milestone" ==> fix is not in.

<sigh>  I was just checking.  Looking at the fix date I was going on the possibility that the Target Milestone field perhaps was not updated.  Normally what priority bugs are backported into bugfix releases?

>Normally what priority bugs are backported into bugfix releases?
There's no automated back-porting. This is decided individually by the component lead. The bug must either be quite severe (critical or blocker) or very important to clients. In addition it also depends how risky the fix would be.
*** Bug 149558 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
